results.content: It’s an ok course, I think it was weird that it was introduced by one guy who sounded really professional, and then shifted over to an Indian guy who speaks a bit of broken English. I don’t care that much, as the new instructor is getting through the content of the course alright, but it felt like a bit of false advertising that was intentional, and I don’t like feeling like the wool is being pulled over my eyes. Also, the course kind of spends a lot of time on individual tags, showing all the variants of lists and so on, which are pretty self-explanatory once you get the concept, instead of showing how HTML works altogether and mixing tags, and showing the power of attributes in more depth. This might be ok if I was a complete newbie but I know all the basics of HTML, and it feels a bit amateurish for my taste so far. I’m hoping that changes later in the course.

results.content: I'm about 20% of the way through, and so far it's a bit disappointing. This course claims to have two co-teachers, but in reality the whole thing is taught by some guy who is presumably a good web dev but misuses simple words like "know" and "teach." Some of the lessons could be boiled down to 15 seconds, but instead they take up 3-4 minutes. Over time, all the excess hellos and goodbyes add up and make the course much less efficient. If the remainder of the course is notably better or worse, I will update. I used a discount code for the course and would recommend that if you can't get this course for free, look elsewhere for other content.

One student who asked for the lecture to be clearer got an answer to buy the next course. What? No. Rerecord the lecture and annunciate better. I really don't like writing bad reviews because I want to see people succeed, but I also want to see instructors provide quality content, and in this case, there are people on youtube who provide better instruction for free than the 200 sandbagged dollars being asked for this course. 

I would avoid this as well as the HTML5 course as well. There are much better ones available.

results.content:
The demonstrations given in each section are not well planned.  You can tell the instructor is making stuff up as he goes.  Often the example turns into several minutes of trying different pixel widths to make things look decent.  That adds no value to the subject at hand.

The audio quality is very poor.

Although Shahzaib is not a native English speaker, I actually did not find him too hard to understand.  He has an accent, but I got used to it fairly quick.  Watch & listen to the preview before you take the course.

The course material would be much better if everything had been scripted out ahead of time.  I also think the videos would each be 30% shorter!

results.content:
Slightly difficult to understand however, a solid beginner course to HTML & CSS. I feel I must point out though, this is for complete novices, not intermediates and you will NOT be a professional at the end of this course but you will have a good handling of the HTML & CSS language.

Instructors delivery can be a little repetitive and none explanatory at times as well. Sometimes he glosses over important elements with little explanation as to what those elements actually do and WHY they do them.

Overall, a 7/10.
